routing_summary.excerpt_summary: Introductory and overview material: defines TLS goals and properties, normative language conventions, relationship to RFC 8446 and older TLS versions, enumerates technical deltas from TLS 1.2, and lists optional updates that affect TLS 1.2.

Temporal.explanation: Mostly static descriptions of properties and high-level changes; no concrete event ordering or state machines here.

ActorDirectionality.explanation: Client/server roles are described in broad terms only; nothing that would drive a directional inconsistency on its own.

Scope.explanation: Mentions which parts of the document apply to TLS 1.2 vs 1.3, but this is high-level and appears internally consistent.

Causal.explanation: Descriptive text about goals and properties, not executable algorithms where cause–effect chains could break.

Quantitative.explanation: No field sizes, ranges, counters, or limits in this section that could be internally inconsistent.

Deontic.explanation: Uses BCP 14 boilerplate and a few summary bullets of new MUST/SHOULDs, but the actual normative details are elsewhere.

Structural.explanation: No ABNF/YANG/ASN.1 in this section; only prose and bullets.

CrossRFC.explanation: Cross-RFC references (5077, 5246, 5705, 6066, 6961, 8996, 9525) match the intended roles and are consistent with how RFC 8446 already treated them.

Terminology.explanation: Definitions of “client”, “server”, “handshake”, etc. are standard and used consistently; the “master”→“main” renaming is clearly flagged as editorial/terminological.

Boundary.explanation: No edge-case behaviors described here; those appear later in protocol details.
